lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re Ken Hao's Oct. 23 letter headlined ''Truth About Preferences,'' in which he says ''race trumps sex as a factor in negative social impact'': Is there ever an excuse for discrimination? Years ago on my first job the male supervisor didn't think twice in brushing away my discovery of the pay gap between male and female college graduates in the same job by saying men had to ''support families.''

snippet: LEAD: FORGET the image of the male grocery shopper of the 1950's: sent to the store for a can of peaches, he came home with a sheepish look and a jar of chocolate-covered ants. Working women and job-sharing at home have changed all that. Men are g...
lead_paragraph: LEAD: FORGET the image of the male grocery shopper of the 1950's: sent to the store for a can of peaches, he came home with a sheepish look and a jar of chocolate-covered ants. Working women and job-sharing at home have changed all that. Men are going to the grocery store in record numbers, and while some still break out in a cold sweat just walking through the automatic door, far more are at ease in the aisles and thoroughly capable of distinguishing between a mango and a papaya.

headline.main: DEBUNKING MYTHS OF THE MALE SHOPPER

snippet: As nearly 10,000 scholars of English and world literature gathered here this weekend for the centennial convention of the Modern Language Association, many participants spent more time job-hunting than intellectualizing.   ''I have six interviews ...
lead_paragraph: As nearly 10,000 scholars of English and world literature gathered here this weekend for the centennial convention of the Modern Language Association, many participants spent more time job-hunting than intellectualizing. ''I have six interviews today and six more tomorrow,'' said Danny Anderson, a doctoral candidate at the University of Kansas who is looking for a job teaching Spanish and is also fluent in Portuguese. ''My entire day has been running around to interviews and waiting for interviews. I am exhausted.''

headline.main: SCHOLARS SEEKING JOBS IN LANGUAGES

snippet: The share of men aged 25 to 54 who are not working has more than tripled since the late 1960s, with many having decided that low-wage jobs will not improve their lives....
lead_paragraph: The share of men aged 25 to 54 who are not working has more than tripled since the late 1960s, with many having decided that low-wage jobs will not improve their lives.
abstract: Percentage of American men between 25 and 54 years of age who are without paying jobs has tripled since late 1960s, to 16 percent, as United States employment rate falls toward bottom of list of developed nations; although many of nation's unemployed are eager to join work force, large numbers, particularly men, are choosing not to work at all until they find jobs that pay living wage and provide benefits (Series: Nonemployed).

headline.main: The Vanishing Male Worker: How America Fell Behind
headline.print_headline: The Vanishing Male Worker, Waiting It Out

snippet: The two-career family in which both the husband and wife can rear their  children without penalty to their careers is a new family pattern that must be more widely encouraged, corporate leaders were told here last week....
lead_paragraph: The two-career family in which both the husband and wife can rear their children without penalty to their careers is a new family pattern that must be more widely encouraged, corporate leaders were told here last week.
abstract: Catalyst (orgn) pres Felice N Schwartz says 2-career family in which both wife and husband can rear their children without penalty to their careers is new family pattern that must be encouraged, speech to corp leaders; predicts that acceptance of 2-career family pattern, in which child care is shared equally, might require vast changes, which could take several generations to achieve (S)

snippet: Where industrial jobs have grown scarce, nurses and other health care professionals are increasingly leading the way to middle-income lifestyles....
lead_paragraph: Where industrial jobs have grown scarce, nurses and other health care professionals are increasingly leading the way to middle-income lifestyles.
abstract: Tabitha Waugh, registered nurse in Huntington, West Virginia, epitomizes how the health care profession is increasingly providing inroads to the middle class as industrial jobs grow scarce; Waugh earns $27 per hour and has become main breadwinner for her family of four; health care industry now provides 4.5 million middle-class positions, up from just 1.4 million in 1980 (Series: A Shifting Middle).

snippet: Ai-jen Poo fights for domestic workers’ rights....
lead_paragraph: It’s the most intimate class divide in human civilization, or at least in such relatively civilized places as Manhattan and Park Slope, Brooklyn. On the one side, there is the professional couple bringing in six figures a year; on the other, the nanny or maid without whom the couple wouldn’t be able to practice their professions. Conditions of employment are as variable as the individual employers are — from respectful and considerate all the way to criminally abusive. On average, a domestic worker is likely to get less than $15 an hour, no benefits and none of the credit or glory. To my knowledge anyway, there has never been a successful career woman — or man, for that matter — who’s responded to being praised for “doing it all” by saying, “Actually, Manuela (or Angelica or Harriet) does most of it.”
abstract: Ai-jen Poo fights for domestic workers’ rights.

headline.main: The Nannies’ Norma Rae

snippet: Stronger employment protections for transgender people make good social policy and business sense....
lead_paragraph: Stronger employment protections for transgender people make good social policy and business sense.
abstract: Editorial relates difficulty that 24-year-old college graduate Elaine Rita Mendus has had in finding job in New York City due to fact that she is transgender; points to Mendus's story as indicative of how transgender community is economically disadvantaged and faces widespread employment discrimination; calls for federal law that would protect lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people from discrimination (Series: Transgender Today).

headline.main: The Struggle for Fairness for Transgender Workers

snippet: The need to constantly adapt is the new reality for anyone whose job is touched by computing — not just to change careers, but simply to stay competitive on one’s chosen path....
lead_paragraph: The need to constantly adapt is the new reality for anyone whose job is touched by computing — not just to change careers, but simply to stay competitive on one’s chosen path.
abstract: Workers in a wide cross-section of fields that use computers find themselves having to constantly learn and adapt to new platforms and technological frontiers in order merely to stay afloat in their careers; expectation of constant improvement and change has led many to turn to bite-size instructional videos, peer-to-peer forums and virtual college courses (Series: The New American Job).

headline.seo: To Stay Relevant in a Career, Workers Train Nonstop
headline.main: To Stay Relevant in a Career, Workers Train Nonstop
headline.print_headline: Working Nonstop to Stay Relevant
